title: Public service HR overhaul to spark competition with private sector
text:
"The competition for talent is very real and, I have to say, they've got the jump start on us and we need to be out there selling ourselves properly and what we do.

"There are certain things we have that are really important. We need to do a better job in promoting that. They include the fact you get to make a difference to people's lives, you do get to really contribute to society."

Jacqui Curtis, the new HR head of profession, and chief operating officer of the Australian Taxation Office. Sitthixay Ditthavong

A former ambassador and chief of staff to then prime minister Malcolm Turnbull, Mr Woolcott said better promoting the benefits of government employment would benefit policy and service delivery.

"We do provide work-life balance and quite a flexible operating environment and we're obviously very focused on inclusion and diversity," he said. "We've got a good story to tell."

Ms Curtis will hold the new role in addition to her full-time position at the Tax Office.

"One of the most important things for the HR community is to be able to connect up together. Even in agencies today, they are very siloed," she said.

"Bringing those people together, either virtually or physically, is one of the most important things to share the strategies, connect the ideas and their initiatives so they're able to have a bigger impact."

Other areas of government operations, including technology and procurement, are slated for similar strategies as soon as 2020.

In August, Prime Minister Scott Morrison urged the Thodey panel to take a tougher line on performance standards.

The average federal public servant is a woman aged 43, located in Canberra and with 11 years of service. Only about 38 per cent of public servants are based in the national capital, with the rest spread around the country and overseas in 105 agencies.

The final Thodey report, commissioned in March 2018 by Mr Turnbull, was handed to Mr Morrison last month.

Last week Finance Minister Mathias Cormann flagged a relaxing of the government's staffing cap for the public service, telling Senate estimates "that environment has changed" as the federal budget returns to surplus.

Experts believe the cap on employment has led to increasing spend on government outsourcing and consulting contracts.
description: Changes to how the federal government workforce recruits and manages its human resources are designed to improve service delivery and competition.
